newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Opposition planes bomb northern Afghan city.
newsitem.headline: Opposition planes bomb northern Afghan city.

text.p: Opposition jets staged two bombing raids on the Taleban-held city of Kunduz in northern Afghanistan on Saturday, a Pakistan-based Afghan news service said.
The Afghan Islamic Press (AIP) said it had no immediate word on casualties or damage from the air strikes.
It quoted Taleban sources as saying its forces in Kunduz had beaten back five opposition ground attacks in the past four days, capturing 218 fighters and four of their commanders.
The Taleban sources said at least 16 opposition guerrillas had been killed and 50 wounded in the battles, while 11 Taleban fighters had been killed.
Opposition spokesmen could not be contacted for comment and no independent account of the fighting was available.
Dr Abdullah (one name), an aide to ethnic Tajik opposition commander Ahmad Shah Masood, said on Thursday that the Taleban forces in Kunduz must surrender or fight.
"Our groups are stationed close to Kunduz and if the Taleban and their allies don't leave the area...then we will be forced to take it by military means," Abdullah said.

He said Masood, whose forces are loyal to ousted president Burhanuddin Rabbani, could not tolerate the Taleban's presence in Kunduz, which fell to the purist Islamic militia last week after a local opposition commander, Arif Khan, switched sides.
Abdullah had said talks were under way with Khan to persuade him to hand over Taleban fighters, who had come to Kunduz from Baghlan province further south.
The Taleban, who seized Kabul in September, are trying to impose strict Islamic rule throughout Afghanistan.
